intro: Corydalis ochotensis var. raddeana, commonly known as the Siberian Corydalis, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Eastern Siberia and northern Mongolia. It belongs to the family Fumariaceae and is characterized by its delicate, spurred flowers that typically bloom in shades of pink and purple. The plant features slender, creeping stems and lance-shaped leaves with a hairy texture. It thrives in cool, moist environments and is often found in rocky or forested areas. Due to its ornamental value and limited distribution, it is considered a rare and sometimes endangered species in its native habitat.
